author: By Mike Ives
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Coronavirus, Ireland, Oscars: Here’s what you need to know.
content: As many people across China return to work today after an already-extended Lunar New Year break, the country is confronting two bleak statistics:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Iran Again Fails to Put Satellite Into Orbit
description: Repeated failures with a communications satellite don’t halt an official’s assertions that the country is “UNSTOPPABLE!”
content: TEHRAN, Iran (AP) — Iran tried but failed to put a satellite into orbit on Sunday, state television reported, the latest setback for work that the United States says helps Tehran advance its ballistic missile program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: phantasmagoria
description: This word has appeared in 11 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘How 17 Outsize Portraits Rattled a Small Southern Town’
description: In this lesson, students will explore how a public art installation led a town to look at itself closely. Then they will consider how they would best represent their own community.
content: Featured Article: “How 17 Outsize Portraits Rattled a Small Southern Town” by Audra D. S. Burch
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Accessory Storage
description: Treasured jewelry and accessories deserve safekeeping. Don’t just dump them all in a bag.
content: If you don’t wear all of your jewelry and accessories round the clock — and all at the same time — you need somewhere to store them. But not all storage methods are equally kind to treasured pieces.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Money, Morality and a Challenge to Silicon Valley
description: The investor Chamath Palihapitiya urged start-ups and venture capitalists to reconsider where they get their money from, in light of a new report on a Mormon Church mega-fund.
content: On our radar: L Brands is said to be close to a deal to sell control of Victoria’s Secret to the investment firm Sycamore Partners. (Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Actual Decadence!
description: Valentine’s Day is on Friday: Why not serve a loved one — or yourself — a caviar sandwich?
content: Good morning. Valentine’s Day is Friday, a Hallmark holiday for some, with cards and chocolates and roses of questionable provenance, dinners in candlelight, public displays of affection set to stun. If you’re celebrating, I hope you have your reservations made or your caviar order in. You don’t want to be scrambling around on Thursday or Friday morning, looking for ideas. When you serve a loved one this sandwich (above) for Valentine’s dinner, you don’t want it to be an improvisational jam. You want it to be a planned moment of louche luxury: actual decadence, sexy in the extreme.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: A Driverless Oscars Takes a Winding Road
description: Without a host for a second year, the ceremony offered a grab bag of emotional moments and head-scratching choices.
content: The Oscars are now an ensemble production.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Rhyne, Josh Haner and Calla Kessler
title: Come to the Oscars With Brad Pitt and Us
description: What we saw on the Oscars red carpet.
content: What we saw on the Oscars red carpet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: On Politics: This Is Sparta (or Manchester)
description: The Sanders-Buttigieg attacks grow, and a Biden ad gets sarcastic. This is your morning tip sheet.
content: Sandra Day O’Harris, a dog named after Sandra Day O’Connor, waiting with the crowd at Pete Buttigieg’s “Get Out the Vote” campaign stop in Nashua, N.H., on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: 2 Police Officers Injured in Shooting at Walmart in Arkansas, Officials Say
description: The officers were responding to a report that a man was making threats in the grocery section of the store, the police chief said.
content: At least two police officers were injured and a suspect was killed at a Walmart store in Forrest City, Ark., after a person opened fire on Monday, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: What’s Better Than Planting a Trillion Trees?
description: Protecting the forests while we are at it.
content: NASHVILLE — After what seemed like 100 years of impeachments hearings, anything uttered on Capitol Hill now sounds to my ear like the voice of Charlie Brown’s teacher. Nevertheless, a few words from President Trump’s State of the Union address managed to break through the wah-wahs last week: “To protect the environment, days ago, I announced the United States will join the One Trillion Trees Initiative, an ambitious effort to bring together government and the private sector to plant new trees in America and around the world,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez
title: Philippines Moves to Shut ABS-CBN, Its Leading Broadcast Network
description: It’s the latest push by the administration of President Rodrigo Duterte against media outlets he views as critical of his government.
content: MANILA — The Philippine government moved Monday to end the franchise of the country’s leading broadcast network, the latest push by the administration of President Rodrigo Duterte against media outlets that have been critical of his leadership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Best and Worst Moments of the 2020 Oscars
description: All hail Bong Joon Ho — and Billie Eilish’s puzzled reactions and Janelle Monáe’s red-carpet stunner. Here’s what we were talking about after the ceremony.
content: Going into the 92nd Academy Awards, the headlines were about what we wouldn’t see: no J. Lo, no female filmmakers of top films, almost no people of color in the acting categories. And yet women directors won; so did African-American directors. And the night ended with a history-making victory for “Parasite,” the first South Korean film to win best picture. Here are the highs and lows as we saw them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: An Opera of Suffrage Gets Lost in the Museum
description: “The Mother of Us All,” as much an Americana collection as an opera, was staged in the American sculpture court at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
content: It makes sense to present Virgil Thomson and Gertrude Stein’s “The Mother of Us All” in a museum, because this 1947 opera is something of a museum itself. It’s a surreal, hilarious, poignant pageant about the battle for women’s suffrage that throws together American figures and situations from the 19th century — historical and fictional — with a musical amalgam of state fair, military march and parlor hymn. Watching it is like getting lost in a collection’s visible storage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman
title: Pangolins Are Suspected as a Potential Coronavirus Host
description: The world’s most trafficked mammal may be involved in the Wuhan outbreak, but the evidence is far from clear.
content: In the search for the animal source or sources of the coronavirus epidemic in China, the latest candidate is the pangolin, an endangered, scaly, ant-eating mammal that is imported in huge numbers to Chinese markets for food and medicine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: In Trade for Betts, Another of Astros’ Vanquished Opponents Bulks Up
description: Mookie Betts and David Price, via a reworked trade, will join a Dodgers team looking for payback in 2020. In a twist, the Red Sox will get a shortstop named Jeter.
content: The results of each postseason series are engraved on the inside of the Houston Astros’ 2017 championship rings. Most champions design it that way, but the teams Houston thwarted in 2017 were, perhaps, the most regal of all baseball brands: the Boston Red Sox, the Yankees and the Los Angeles Dodgers. The familiar logos of the vanquished seemed to burnish the Astros’ achievement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Williams Walsh
title: Puerto Rico Reaches Deal to Settle $35 Billion in Debt
description: The agreement with general-obligation bondholders gives them more cash up front and more attractive debt, while costing the territory $1 billion less than previously expected.
content: Puerto Rico has reached a deal with creditors who hold $35 billion in its general obligation bonds, passing an important milestone as it tries to resolve its $129 billion debt crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Bisharat
title: A Kayaker and a 134-Foot Waterfall. What Could Go Wrong?
description: The first — and maybe the last — descent of Salto del Maule. A national kayaking champion dreamed of being the first person to run a 134-foot waterfall in the mountains of Chile.
content: In 1901, Annie Edson Taylor, a 63-year-old schoolteacher, became the first person to go over Niagara Falls in New York in a barrel, a stunt she had hoped would solve her financial problems (it didn’t). The explanations for why one might want to throw oneself off a waterfall range from the allure of glory and the promise of wealth, to an escape from desperation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Randi Hutter Epstein
title: Bruce McEwen, 81, Is Dead; Found Stress Can Alter the Brain
description: A neuroscientist, he showed how an unrelenting barrage of stress hormones can break down the body, leading to disease, depression, obesity and more.
content: It was a staple of medical thinking dating to the 1910s that stress was the body’s alarm system, switching on only when terrible things happened, often leaving a person with an either-or choice: fight or flight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: Amsterdam Considers Apology for Slavery in Former Colony
description: A reckoning is afoot, centuries after the city became a co-owner of what was then the South American colony of Suriname.
content: AMSTERDAM — The most enduring legacy of slavery in the Netherlands may be found in neighborhoods like Bijlmermeer, a working-class corner of Amsterdam where many — including those who trace their heritage to the former colony of Suriname — have long felt sidelined.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag
title: Sorry, Renters: You Still Have to Pay Brokers’ Fees for Now
description: A New York judge temporarily blocked a new state rule barring brokers from charging tenants.
content: A New York State judge on Monday temporarily blocked the state’s week-old ruling that had effectively barred tenants from having to pay a broker fee, issuing at least a short-term reprieve to an industry scrambling to respond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman
title: Pangolins Are Suspected as a Potential Coronavirus Host
description: The world’s most trafficked mammal may be involved in the Wuhan outbreak, but the evidence is far from clear.
content: In the search for the animal source or sources of the coronavirus epidemic in China, the latest candidate is the pangolin, an endangered, scaly, ant-eating mammal that is imported in huge numbers to Chinese markets for food and medicine.

Most champions design it that way, but the teams Houston thwarted in 2017 were, perhaps, the most regal of all baseball brands: the Boston Red Sox, the Yankees and the Los Angeles Dodgers. title: Puerto Rico Reaches Deal to Settle $35 Billion in Debt

content: Puerto Rico has reached a deal with creditors who hold $35 billion in its general obligation bonds, passing an important milestone as it tries to resolve its $129 billion debt crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilarie M. Sheets
title: MoMA’s Atrium Set as Theatrical Stage for the Summer
description: A new multimedia installation by Adam Pendleton, with live events daily, will explore the politics and aesthetics of blackness.
content: Adam Pendleton will transform the Museum of Modern Art’s atrium this summer into a theatrical stage set framed by three 60-foot-tall scaffolds displaying his work. The 36-year-old artist’s multimedia installation is titled “Who Is Queen?” and will be on view from July 25 through Oct. 4, with live daily events surrounded by text-based paintings, mobiles, video portraits and sound pieces exploring his concept of “Black Dada.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laurel Graeber
title: Can Puppets Save the World From Extinction?
description: Two new productions use everyday materials and artistic ingenuity to gently warn young audiences of the perils of climate change.
content: As an all-terrain vehicle rumbles through a serene desert valley, its driver unwittingly starts a devastating fire by flicking cigar embers out the window. In another landscape, volcanoes are erupting, acidifying the ocean and threatening the life within it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mariel Padilla
title: Louisiana Man Pleads Guilty to Burning Down Three Black Churches
description: Holden Matthews, 22, said he set fire to the churches last year in an attempt to raise his profile as a musician in a subgenre of heavy metal.
content: A 22-year-old man pleaded guilty on Monday to intentionally setting fires to three predominantly black Baptist churches in Louisiana over a 10-day period last year — crimes that set a rural Cajun community on edge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: 2 Police Officers Injured in Shooting at Walmart in Arkansas, Officials Say
description: The officers were responding to a report that a man was making threats in the grocery section of the store, the police chief said.
content: At least two police officers were injured and a suspect was killed at a Walmart store in Forrest City, Ark., after a person opened fire on Monday, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Shortcuts to a Vietnamese Dinner
description: Slanted Door sauces from the chef Charles Phan are designed to amp up the flavor in stir-fries and slow simmers.
content: Premade simmer sauces have become a big thing for shortcutting Indian cooking at home. Now, Charles Phan, the founder and chef at the Slanted Door restaurant in San Francisco, has taken the same approach to Vietnamese fare. He has introduced four braising sauces, two for quick stir-fries and two for slower simmers; each comes with a simple recipe based on one of the restaurant’s dishes, usually using at least half the jar of sauce. For many seasoning purposes, I liked the nubbly, spicy-sweet chile caramel sauce, recommended for a shrimp stir-fry, but superb with eggplant, chicken or pork belly. The Claypot Chicken quick-braising sauce and Lo Soi Pork sauce for a slow braise were dark, fairly thin and spicy. The ruddy, viscous Vietnamese French braising sauce was quite sweet and to me, less appealing than the others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: What’s Better Than Planting a Trillion Trees?
description: Protecting the forests while we are at it.
content: NASHVILLE — After what seemed like 100 years of impeachments hearings, anything uttered on Capitol Hill now sounds to my ear like the voice of Charlie Brown’s teacher. title: Quotation of the Day: 18 Deadly Hours Shake Thailand to Its Roots
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, February 10, 2020.
content: “The society nowadays has turned into this? It’s devastating. My heart can’t handle it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by John Otis and Michael Gonchar
title: How Much Do You Know About Nigeria?
description: Can you find Nigeria on a map? What else do you know about this African nation with about 206 million people?
content: Can you find Nigeria on a map? What else do you know about this African nation with about 206 million people?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: The Marketing of Stimulants for Children With A.D.H.D.
description: Doctors must balance patients’ needs, parents’ concerns, pressure from pharmaceutical representatives and challenges from insurance companies.
content: Whenever I write about attention deficit hyperactivity disorder — whether I’m writing generally about the struggles facing these children and their families or dealing more specifically with medications — I know that some readers will write in to say that A.D.H.D. is not a real disorder. They say that the rising numbers of children taking stimulant medication to treat attentional problems are all victims, sometimes of modern society and its unfair expectations, sometimes of doctors, and most often of the rapacious pharmaceutical industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: In the Age of Digital Streaming, Are Movie Theaters Still Relevant?
description: How is watching a movie in a theater different from streaming it at home? On what occasion do you think it’s worth venturing out to see a movie on the big screen? Or, to you, is it never worth it?
content: How often do you watch movies? And where do you like to watch them?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Meet Our New Los Angeles Bureau Chief
description: Monday: Manny Fernandez comes from a stellar run in Texas. But he’s no stranger to the Golden State. Also: A big night for “Parasite” at the Oscars.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Hunter
title: A Grown-Up Bed That Will Last for Years
description: The right frame, mattress, and bedding can promote better rest and pull together the look of your entire room with a lot less effort and money than you might think.
content: Adulting is expensive, and when the bills roll in, blowing a chunk of your paycheck on a new bed can feel daunting. But a good-looking, comfy space to sleep is always a good investment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By MJ Franklin
title: For a Scientist Turned Novelist, an Experiment Pays Off
description: “Real Life” follows a pivotal weekend in the life of a black gay student in the Midwest, something Brandon Taylor said was an effort to write himself into the campus-life genre he loves reading.
content: When he set out to write a novel, Brandon Taylor, a former doctoral student in biochemistry at the University of Wisconsin, approached it like a scientist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Jordan, Elisabeth Egan and Ross MacDonald
title: 50 States of Love
description: From sea to shining sea, here’s a tour of unforgettable fiction that explores matters of the heart.
content: Plunk yourself in an armchair and lose yourself in a tale of love, whether it’s a family saga, “12-hanky weeper" or timeworn classic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $750,000 Homes in California
description: A traditional ranch-style house in the San Fernando Valley, a 1965 cottage on the Russian River and a two-bedroom condominium in San Francisco.
content: This property is in Valley Village, a San Fernando Valley neighborhood nestled between North Hollywood and Studio City. In many ways, it is the quintessential Valley neighborhood, with wide, mostly flat streets lined with single-story houses — many of them, like this one, considered traditional or birdhouse ranch houses, with dovecotes, pitched roofs and diamond-pane windows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns and Nick Corasaniti
title: Sanders and Buttigieg Clash, Aiming for a Two-Person Race
description: The point of the attacks was not to set off mass defections between the left and the center, but rather to consolidate support on one side of the party or the other.
content: HOOKSETT, N.H. — Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont and former Mayor Pete Buttigieg of South Bend, Ind., clashed throughout the day on Sunday, in a combative display of their determination to treat the upcoming New Hampshire primary as a two-person race, with former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. continuing to struggle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Coleman
title: Translating for Bong Joon Ho at the Oscars: Aspiring Director Sharon Choi
description: Choi, who interpreted for the “Parasite” director and others involved with the film, has become a familiar face throughout awards season.
content: Bong Joon Ho was onstage a lot on Sunday night, giving one acceptance speech after another as his film “Parasite” scooped up Oscars, including best picture. Beside him each time was a familiar face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: Why Ranked-Choice Voting Is Having a Moment
description: A few states will use it in their 2020 primaries, and some cities have been using it for years. Proponents say it could make politics more civil. Critics say it could hurt turnout.
content: Presidential election years always raise big questions about the way we vote, in part because the process can get kind of messy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The End of Privacy as We Know It?
description: An unregulated facial recognition app can probably tell the police your name, and help them find out where you live and who your friends are.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: What the Heck Is That?
description: A look at one of the entries from last week’s puzzles that stumped our solvers.
content: An odeon (sometimes spelled “odeum”) was a building used for musical or poetry performances in ancient Greece and Rome. The word comes from the Greek “ōideion,” which is derived from “ōidē,” or “ode.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alison Roman
title: Canned Artichokes Deserve Your Respect
description: There’s something beautiful about trimming an artichoke, but, when the craving strikes, Alison Roman looks to the canned ones, enhanced with dry white wine and savory chicken fat.
content: I love to do things in the kitchen that take up a lot of time, tasks that feel special and maybe a little fussy. Things like soaking precious beans overnight, shucking pounds of fresh peas from their pods, and gingerly trimming thorny raw artichokes to steam and eat with clarified butter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Who Needs a Caribbean Yacht When You Can Take the Ferry?
description: In the British Virgin Islands, get cheap maritime thrills and rub shoulders with locals on one of the region’s most convenient ferry systems.
content: Orion was shining brightly in the dark sky above Anegada in the British Virgin Islands. But the constellation had some electric competition in the band of bright mast lights bobbing offshore — “like a bejeweled Orion’s belt,” observed a new acquaintance who introduced himself as Spoons, the pilot of one of those yachts. He and his crew of five friends from the Boston area had paid $10,900 for eight days on a 45-foot catamaran to sail from island to island.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Dungeness Crabs and Other Delights From the Deep
description: Essex Pearl, a fish market and restaurant in the Market Line food hall on the Lower East Side, carries the popular West Coast crab.
content: Some hard-to-find seafood from across the globe sits alongside the usual fillets of black sea bass and piles of clams at Essex Pearl, a fish market and restaurant in the new Market Line food hall on the Lower East Side from the fishmonger Steven Wong. Tempted by some Maine sea urchins, slender Massachusetts razor clams or a rare blue lobster? They have them on occasion. And now, you’ll find a year-round source for live Pacific Dungeness crabs. Though popular on the West Coast, they’re fairly rare in New York. These substantial two-pounders — currently from the waters off San Francisco and later, from Canada — are ready to steam and enjoy with butter, or have one cooked for you to eat right in the market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Tina Brown on the Future of the Royal Family
description: ‘People are so exhausted by instability that if the monarchy collapsed, that would be massively disruptive.’
content: ‘People are so exhausted by instability that if the monarchy collapsed, that would be massively disruptive.’
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Chocolate Mousse on the Move
description: The Belgian chef Johan Halsberghe has moved his mousse company to East Harlem, where he sells scoops of the chocolate to stay or to go.
content: Johan Halsberghe — a Belgian chef who started making fresh chocolate mousse for high-end markets to sell in little plastic cups a few years ago — has outgrown his Brooklyn kitchen and has moved his production to East Harlem. His new space includes a small dessert bar in the front, where he sells the chocolate mousse in dark, white and hazelnut, like ice cream, freshly scooped into cups, $3 for one scoop, $5 for two, $6 for a sampler, to stay or to go. Some rotating flavors include matcha and passion fruit. Though he knows there is a chocolate mousse bar in Paris, he doesn’t believe that such a sweet spot exists in the United States. Some pastries, coffee and fruit juices are also available.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: How Trump Got Trickled Down
description: He pretended to be different. He was lying.
content: One thing many people forget about the 2016 election is that as a candidate, Donald Trump promised to be a different kind of Republican. Unlike the mainstream of his party, he declared, he would raise taxes on the rich and wouldn’t cut programs like Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid that ordinary Americans rely on. At the same time, he would invest large sums in rebuilding America’s infrastructure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Tobias
title: Where to Stream ‘Parasite’ and Other Big Oscar Winners
description: Nearly all of the night’s winners are available online to stream, rent or buy. Here’s at look at what they are and where to find them.
content: For Oscar viewers eager to catch up with Bong Joon Ho’s “Parasite,” the first-ever non-English-language film to win Best Picture, the timing could not be better for streaming, because it’s just become available for rental. In fact, save for “Little Women,” “1917” and “Bombshell,” which only won in technical categories, every Oscar winner is currently streaming for a fee in digital media stores or on subscription services, and two of the three shorts are posted for free on YouTube. Bong’s twisty genre hybrid about a con that metastasizes into class warfare should be a priority, but it will be easier than usual to find out if the Academy got it right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Seeing the Oscar Challenge to Fashion Week and Raising It One
description: Rachel Comey and Vaquera get New York Fashion Week off to a buzzy start.
content: New York Fashion Week dribbled into existence just after President Trump’s impeachment acquittal victory lap, and in the shadow of the Bernie-Buttigieg squabbles over Iowa. Not to mention the Oscars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: An Alzheimer’s Treatment Fails: ‘We Don’t Have Anything Now’
description: With high hopes, drugs to fight brain plaques were tested in people genetically destined to develop dementia. The drugs failed.
content: The study aimed to show that Alzheimer’s disease could be stopped if treatment began before symptoms emerged. The participants were the best candidates that scientists could find: still healthy, but with a rare genetic mutation that guaranteed they would develop dementia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Oscars Red Carpet: Let’s Give Them Something to Talk About
description: When it came to fashion, it was old Hollywood vs. new. Guess who won.
content: Old Hollywood — and the way it is represented by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and its award nominations — has been under the microscope for a while now, whether because of #OscarsSoWhite or #MeToo or the lack of recognition of female directors (and the lack of recognition of Jennifer Lopez in “Hustlers”! Scandal!).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia and Constant Méheut
title: U.K. Declares Coronavirus ‘Imminent Threat’ as Europe Scrambles
description: The declaration lets English public health officials isolate individuals who may have contracted the virus. It came as the number of cases in the country rose to eight on Monday.
content: LONDON — Britain’s health department declared the new coronavirus an “imminent threat” to public health and announced a series of measures to combat the spread of the virus, a sign of the seriousness with which local health authorities are treating the fears of the epidemic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: As Democrats Try to Move On From the Caucus Chaos
description: Readers continue the discussion about who has the best chance to defeat President Trump as New Hampshire holds its primary.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Half of Us Face Obesity, Dire Projections Show
description: By 2030, nearly one in two adults will be obese, and nearly one in four will be severely obese.
content: Climate change is not the only source of dire projections for the coming decade. Perhaps just as terrifying from both a health and an economic perspective is a predicted continued rise in obesity, including severe obesity, among American adults.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edmund Lee and Andrew Ross Sorkin
title: Judge Is Said to Rule for T-Mobile Merger With Sprint
description: A last-ditch attempt by a coalition of state attorneys general is said to have failed to halt T-Mobile’s purchase of a smaller rival.
content: The judge in a contentious lawsuit that tried to stop the long-in-the-works merger between T-Mobile and Sprint is planning to rule in favor of the deal, according to three people briefed on the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Grim Landmark as Official Death Toll in China Tops 1,000
description: President Xi Jinping, accused of being aloof amid the crisis, made a very public appearance in Beijing.
content: The death toll from the coronavirus epidemic is continuing to climb, Chinese officials said Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What’s in President Trump’s Fiscal 2021 Budget?
description: Steep cuts to domestic programs and more resources for the military and policing the border with Mexico.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump has proposed a record $4.8 trillion budget for the 2021 fiscal year, and while Congress decides what to fund, the document provides a window into the White House’s spending priorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Mitt Romney Is a ‘Judas’ to Many Republicans. But Not in Utah.
description: Some conservatives want to recall him and others want to censure him. In the state he represents, though, many view speaking out against President Trump as an act to admire, not an apostasy.
content: SALT LAKE CITY — Phil Lyman wanted to do something swift and stern.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Half of Us Face Obesity, Dire Projections Show
description: By 2030, nearly one in two adults will be obese, and nearly one in four will be severely obese.
content: Climate change is not the only source of dire projections for the coming decade. Perhaps just as terrifying from both a health and an economic perspective is a predicted continued rise in obesity, including severe obesity, among American adults.

title: Judge Is Said to Rule for T-Mobile Merger With Sprint
description: A last-ditch attempt by a coalition of state attorneys general is said to have failed to halt T-Mobile’s purchase of a smaller rival.
content: The judge in a contentious lawsuit that tried to stop the long-in-the-works merger between T-Mobile and Sprint is planning to rule in favor of the deal, according to three people briefed on the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner and Kenneth P. Vogel
title: Justice Dept. Will Accept Material From Giuliani, but Barr Voices Caution
description: Noting that investigators must consider any information potentially relevant to their work, the attorney general said that evidence from Ukraine could not be taken “at face value.”
content: WASHINGTON — Attorney General William P. Barr said on Monday that the Justice Department would consider information from Rudolph W. Giuliani, President Trump’s personal lawyer, about Ukraine. That could include assertions about former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his son Hunter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: Coronavirus Outbreak Risks Reviving Stigma for China
description: Many of the world’s biggest epidemics have been traced to China. But contagion does not play geographical favorites and the country has made great strides in public health.
content: SARS. Bird flu. And now a new coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in February
description: Our picks for February, including “Rocketman,” “Horsegirl” and “Better Call Saul”
content: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to their libraries. Here are our picks for February.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Some Like It Hot’ and College Basketball
description: A classic romantic comedy by Billy Wilder arrives on the Criterion Channel. And Atlantic Coast Conference rivals square off.
content: SOME LIKE IT HOT (1959) Stream on the Criterion Channel and Amazon. Rent on Google Play, iTunes, Vudu and YouTube. Marilyn Monroe shines in this classic romantic comedy by Billy Wilder. She plays Sugar, a performer who catches the eye of two men, Joe (Tony Curtis) and Jerry (Jack Lemmon), when they join her traveling band for its trip to Miami. The problem is that Joe and Jerry have disguised themselves as women in order to escape the gangsters who are pursuing them in Chicago. To keep safe they have to maintain their false identities, but as long as they do, neither can pursue Sugar. Joe tries to get around this issue by reinventing himself as Junior, an heir to an oil fortune. Regarded now as a cinematic treasure for its meticulous construction and timeless laughs, the film is also notable for including several music performances by Monroe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Some Like It Hot’ and College Basketball
description: A classic romantic comedy by Billy Wilder arrives on the Criterion Channel. And Atlantic Coast Conference rivals square off.

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: ‘Hair Love’ Receives a Lot of Love at the Oscars for Best Animated Short Film
description: The animated short centers on an African-American father who is learning how to style his daughter’s natural hair for the first time.
content: At the Oscars, it’s the big-ticket categories that tend to draw the most attention, but this year the winner for animated short rose to prominence.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Oscar Winners 2020: The Complete List
description: Here are the winners of the 92nd Academy Awards.
content: Here are the winners of the 92nd Academy Awards:

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Janelle Monáe Highlights Diversity and Snubbed Films in Oscars Opener
description: Her musical number honored black artists and female directors. It also brought up films that were not nominated, including “Us” and “Midsommar.”
content: The opening musical number of the Oscars on Sunday had all the glitz and glam associated with the biggest night in Hollywood: the singer-songwriter Janelle Monáe in a tuxedo top, a large cast of backup dancers and sparks flying from the back of the stage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Nick Taylor Pulls Away From Mickelson to Win at Pebble Beach
description: Taylor’s second career PGA Tour victory was a big one. It gets him into the Masters for the first time, along with the P.G.A. Championship.
content: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. — Nick Taylor had more trouble with the wind than he did with Phil Mickelson. Taylor, a Canadian, managed both just fine on Sunday and won the Pebble Beach Pro-Am for his second career victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum
title: She Ran Over and Killed 2 Children. Should She Have Had a Car?
description: With traffic deaths spiking, New York City is targeting those who accumulate red-light and speeding violations.
content: A driver in Brooklyn with eight violations for speeding or running a red light killed a 5-year-old girl and a 1-year-old boy. An 85-year-old woman was killed by another Brooklyn driver with 10 speeding violations and two red-light violations. In Manhattan, a driver with two speeding tickets crushed a bicycle courier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roe Ethridge
title: ‘Silver Point,’ a Short Fashion Film by Roe Ethridge
description: The models Elibeidy Dani and Janaye Furman wear Marc Jacobs’s spring 2020 collection.

content: The New York Times writers and critics Dave Itzkoff, Cara Buckley and Wesley Morris provided live commentary during the 92nd Academy Awards. Read their reactions and analysis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zengerle
title: Pick Me, Mr. President!
description: For Republican candidates in Alabama’s Senate race, winning the primary means doing whatever it takes to score one very important endorsement.
content: In early November, President Trump announced he would be traveling to Tuscaloosa, Ala., to attend the University of Alabama-Louisiana State University football game. When Representative Bradley Byrne, a three-term congressman and United States Senate candidate from Mobile, learned of this plan, he immediately called an Alabama booster named Jim Wilson, who would be hosting Trump in his luxury box near midfield at Bryant-Denny Stadium. Wilson, as fortune would have it, is a distant relative, friend and financial supporter of Byrne’s, and Byrne thought perhaps he could get him into the box.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles and Natalie Kitroeff
title: What Needs to Happen to Get Boeing’s 737 Max Flying Again?
description: The plane could be back in the air relatively soon, but the company, regulators and airlines must do several things first.
content: Boeing’s 737 Max could be flying again before too long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Wood, Collin O'Mara and Dale Hall
title: Trump Weakens the Nation’s Clean Water Efforts
description: The president’s decision to roll back protections is deeply misguided.
content: The Environmental Protection Agency made a startling admission last month when it announced that many of the nation’s streams and wetlands would no longer be protected under the Clean Water Act, perhaps the nation’s most successful antipollution law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Albright and Igor Ivanov
title: A Plea to Save the Last Nuclear Arms Treaty
description: Two former diplomats, from Russia and America, call for extending the nuclear arms limitation pact called New START, to make the world more secure.
content: The relationship between Russia and the United States has been mired in crisis for much of the past decade. Communication once considered routine has been cut off, deepening mistrust and making it more difficult to reduce tensions and avoid miscalculation. The current state of affairs does not serve the strategic interests of either country, and it puts global security at risk because Russia and the United States are the only countries that possess enough nuclear weapons to destroy each other — and all of humanity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Gaddis
title: Why Are You Still Packing Lunch for Your Kids?
description: While parents have been focusing on creating Instagram-friendly school lunches, the quality of cafeteria food has improved significantly.
content: Parents today face a steady stream of advice about how best to care for their children. Mothers, in particular, are pressured to be the perfect parent: Most of the advice on social media and parenting blogs is directed at them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Killing of Terrorist Leader in Yemen Is Latest Blow to Qaeda Affiliate
description: The death of Qassim al-Rimi is part of a string of setbacks that have damaged the group’s ability to carry out operations against the West.
content: WASHINGTON — For more than a decade, Al Qaeda’s affiliate in Yemen has been one of the most dangerous terrorist organizations on the planet. The group spent years inventing explosives that are difficult to detect, including trying to disguise bombs in devices like cellphones. It has tried at least three times to blow up American airliners, without success.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Iliana Magra
title: Storm Ciara, or Sabine, Leaves 5 Dead in Europe
description: A powerful winter storm battered Europe on Sunday, leaving power outages, transportation chaos and at least five deaths in its wake.
content: LONDON — Streets were flooded, flights were canceled, traffic was jammed, power was cut and wind-blown trees blocked roads and rails on Monday as a deadly winter storm raged through western and northern Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Russia Sentences Anti-Fascists on Bogus Terror Charges, Critics Say
description: The young men received sentences of up to 18 years on the basis of confessions obtained under torture, their lawyers and rights advocates say.
content: MOSCOW — A Russian military court on Monday handed down harsh sentences of up to 18 years to seven members of a group of left-wing activists, who in turn accused the authorities of extorting confessions through torture and threats against their families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canadian Police Move Against Pipeline Blockades, Arresting Dozens
description: The protesters, lending support to an Indigenous campaign against a natural gas pipeline, brought rail service and ports to a halt.
content: OTTAWA — The Canadian police on Monday began moving against protesters who had set up transportation blockades around the country in sympathy with an Indigenous group’s campaign to halt construction of a natural gas pipeline to Canada’s West Coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shola Lawal
title: Africa, a Thunder and Lightning Hot Spot, May See Even More Storms
description: The size and frequency of  thunderstorms has risen along with global temperatures, researchers at the University of Tel Aviv found.
content: Africa is experiencing bigger and more frequent thunderstorms as global temperatures rise, according to researchers at Tel Aviv University.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers
title: ‘Let’s Not Shake Hands’: Xi Jinping Tours Beijing Amid Coronavirus Crisis
description: China’s leader, who rarely mingles with the public, visited several sites in the capital and spoke to medical workers in Wuhan via video conferencing.
content: BEIJING — When he stepped inside the municipal office five miles north of the Forbidden City, China’s most powerful leader in decades pulled up the sleeve of his black overcoat and held out his wrist. A woman in a mask and surgical gloves then checked to see if he had a fever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Motoko Rich
title: Cruise Ship’s Coronavirus Outbreak Leaves Crew Nowhere to Hide
description: Cases of the new virus on the quarantined Diamond Princess reached 135 Monday, including 20 Americans. Conditions below decks could risk further spread.
content: YOKOHAMA, Japan — In the passenger decks of the quarantined Diamond Princess cruise ship, more than 2,500 travelers are carefully isolated. Meals are delivered to their cabins. They have permission to walk on deck, six feet apart, for a few minutes a day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery
title: Your Foam Coffee Cup Is Fighting for Its Life
description: The Dart Container Corporation, which makes foam products, is a manufacturing behemoth and produced a fortune for the family behind it. Environmentalists say its products are polluting the globe.
content: MASON, Mich. — The Dart Container Corporation, by some measures, is an American success story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: Man Who Shot Up a Bronx Precinct Was ‘Tired of Police Officers’
description: Robert Williams, who the police said wounded two officers in a weekend rampage, had a long criminal history.
content: When Robert L. Williams walked out of Elmira state prison three years ago, he was a free man for the first time in nearly 15 years. He was 43 and had spent half his life in prison. His last crime spree had ended in a gun battle with the police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery
title: Federal Bill Seeks to Make Companies Responsible for Plastic Waste
description: The legislation, to be introduced Tuesday, has little chance of becoming a law, but the effort shows the increased influence of environmental groups in taking on recycling issues.
content: Recycle that plastic bottle. Drink from a reusable water bottle. Stop eating from foam takeout containers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Westminster Dog Show Photos: Almost Ready for Prime Time
description: A field of hundreds will be narrowed to seven by Tuesday night, but on Monday it is still any dog’s game.
content: They gave the hounds and the herders the once over at the Westminster Dog Show on Sunday. The bassets and the beagles, the collies and the corgis. Monday is terrier day, but also showtime for the toy and nonworking groups. The Havanese and the Maltese, the Finnish Spitz and the French Bulldogs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis, Wesley Morris and A.O. Scott
title: What the ‘Parasite’ Landslide Says About the Oscars: Our Critics Weigh In
description: “Parasite” seemed like a surprise, but look at it from another angle and it just may be the ideal movie for the academy.
content: The morning after the Oscars and the historic best-picture win for Bong Joon Ho’s “Parasite,” the first South Korean film to take that prize in 92 years of competition, we asked Manohla Dargis and A.O. Scott, our co-chief film critics, and Wesley Morris, a critic at large, to discuss their reactions and what it means, if anything, for the academy, specifically, and Hollywood in general. Here’s what they said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Carney
title: Why Bernie Sanders Praised Amazon
description: My company deserves scrutiny. But we have already done many of the things politicians demand of America’s leading businesses.
content: “Hello, Jay?” The voice on the line was instantly recognizable. “It’s Bernie Sanders.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Andrew Yang’s Campaign Is Riding on New Hampshire
description: The political outsider did not get pledged delegates (or a boost) from Iowa and is in need of money and momentum. Can Granite State voters keep his campaign viable?
content: EXETER, N.H. — They say all politics is local. And for many months, the entrepreneur Andrew Yang has been dutifully reminding New Hampshire voters that he went to high school at Phillips Exeter Academy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: ‘Like Europe in Medieval Times’: Virus Slows China’s Economy
description: Workers can’t return to their jobs as supply lines get snarled, extending the forced holiday and fracturing the country.
content: Workers are stuck in their hometowns. Officials want detailed health plans before factories or offices can reopen. Assembly lines that make General Motors cars and Apple iPhones are standing silent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabriel Leung
title: The Urgent Questions Scientists Are Asking About Coronavirus
description: Let’s start with what we don’t know.
content: GENEVA — Around the world and around the clock, scientists are trying to figure out what must be done to end the global health emergency unleashed by the new coronavirus. As the outbreak accelerates and spreads, dozens of countries have deployed increasingly stringent measures to try to contain the epidemic. Almost as quickly, in a herculean effort, an international network of researchers at data and wet laboratories has started gathering and analyzing data to unmask and disarm this perplexing new disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: More Than 100 Troops Have Brain Injuries From Iran Missile Strike, Pentagon Says
description: The number of troops injured has steadily increased since the Jan. 8 attack.
content: More than 100 American service members have traumatic brain injuries from Iranian airstrikes on Al Asad Air Base in Iraq in January, the Defense Department said, a number that was more than 50 percent higher than previously disclosed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Decision Time Nears in New Hampshire
description: With decision time just two days away, scores of New Hampshire voters on Sunday — and some political tourists — flocked to school gyms and hotel ballrooms to get a glimpse of the Democratic candidates as they made their closing arguments
content: With decision time just two days away, scores of New Hampshire voters on Sunday — and some political tourists — flocked to school gyms and hotel ballrooms to get a glimpse of the Democratic candidates as they made their closing arguments
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Feb. 10, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Feb. 10, 2020.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Feb. 10, 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: Sinn Fein on Threshold: Party With Old I.R.A. Ties Soars in Irish Election
description: Once ostracized over its ties to sectarian violence, Sinn Fein may now be able to claim a seat at the government table.
content: DUBLIN — Sinn Fein, a leftist party long ostracized from Irish politics over its ties to sectarian violence, won the popular vote and seized its largest-ever share of parliamentary seats in the country’s national elections this weekend, according to results released on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Decision Time Nears in New Hampshire
description: With decision time just two days away, scores of New Hampshire voters on Sunday — and some political tourists — flocked to school gyms and hotel ballrooms to get a glimpse of the Democratic candidates as they made their closing arguments
content: With decision time just two days away, scores of New Hampshire voters on Sunday — and some political tourists — flocked to school gyms and hotel ballrooms to get a glimpse of the Democratic candidates as they made their closing arguments
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: ‘Genius’ Trailer: Cynthia Erivo Plays Aretha Franklin
description: A teaser trailer for the latest season of the National Geographic anthology series offered a first look at Erivo’s portrayal of the Queen of Soul.
content: During the commercial break that came after Cynthia Erivo’s performance at the Academy Awards Sunday night, audiences watching at home got their first taste of one of Erivo’s upcoming projects: Her portrayal of Aretha Franklin in the National Geographic series “Genius.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Feb. 10, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Feb. 10, 2020.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Feb. 10, 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: British Airways Sets Record for Fastest Subsonic Flight From New York to London
description: The flight, which took four hours and 56 minutes, reached a top speed of 825 miles per hour, according to flight-tracking data.
content: No, the Concorde hasn’t made a triumphant return.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gary Santaniello
title: The Beanpot, Boston’s Provincial Hockey Tournament, Gets a Global Boost
description: The annual rivalry for Eastern Massachusetts bragging rights is being contested with players from around the world.
content: BOSTON — The Beanpot remains the most parochial of college hockey tournaments, as much a part of Boston’s fabric as the marathon in April and the Fourth of July fireworks on the Charles River Esplanade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Motion Picture Academy Museum Will Open in December
description: The museum, nine decades in the making and costing at least $388 million, was originally set to open in 2017.
content: LOS ANGELES — The long-delayed Academy Museum of Motion Pictures will open on Dec. 14, completing a nine-decade quest by the Hollywood establishment to celebrate itself year-round.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: Sinn Fein on Threshold: Party With Old I.R.A. Ties Soars in Irish Election
description: Once ostracized over its ties to sectarian violence, Sinn Fein may now be able to claim a seat at the government table.
content: DUBLIN — Sinn Fein, a leftist party long ostracized from Irish politics over its ties to sectarian violence, won the popular vote and seized its largest-ever share of parliamentary seats in the country’s national elections this weekend, according to results released on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: 2020 Oscars Broadcast Hits a New Ratings Low
description: Many television viewers tuned out the 92nd Academy Awards show. Was it the 40 minutes of commercials? A crowded TV season? The lack of a host?
content: Viewership for the Oscars plunged to a new low on Sunday night, with an audience of 23.6 million tuning in to watch the broadcast on ABC, according to Nielsen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Widdicombe and Nicole Sperling
title: Inside the 2020 Oscar Parties
description: Brad Pitt, Bong Joon Ho, Renée Zellweger and Joaquin Phoenix at the Governors Ball and the Vanity Fair party.
content: LOS ANGELES — For those not invited to this year’s Academy Awards, the second-best option might have been the viewing party and dinner hosted by Vanity Fair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A New Company Vying for Your Dinner Plate
description: Ipsa Provisions serves uncommon frozen dinners like Moroccan chicken.
content: Suppose you just want dinner, instead of making your own or opening a delivered collection of premeasured components. Enter Ipsa Provisions, a frozen food company from Micah Fredman, a chef who worked at several restaurants, including Gramercy Tavern, and Joshua Brau, who was at Chipotle and Blue Apron. Among the company’s mostly uncommon offerings — sold online without subscription for delivery in Manhattan and Brooklyn — are a rich mushroom-filled chicken potpie, a brash Korean beef kimchi stew with chewy rice cakes, Moroccan braised chicken with vegetables and fruit, and a deeply caramelized fruit crumble. There’s also a first-rate ragù Bolognese. The main dishes, which serve two to three, are $21 to $25; there are vegetarian options. Defrosting overnight is recommended before reheating for some dishes, but there are some possible shortcuts, like submerging the container in warm water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: A Solution to the D.N.C.’s Iowa Problem
description: Involve all regions of the country in a shared first round of voting.
content: After the debacle last week in Iowa and the reporting of the results there, even more people began to speak openly about how anachronistic and antiquated it is for Iowa and its problematic caucuses to continue to have such an outsize influence on the Democratic nominating process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Suspected Boko Haram Fighters Kill at Least 30 in Nigeria
description: Boko Haram fighters in Nigeria’s northeastern Borno region set ablaze several trucks carrying passengers on Sunday night, eyewitnesses and residents told Reuters.
content: ABUJA, Nigeria — At least 30 people have been killed in Nigeria’s northeastern Borno region after suspected Boko Haram fighters set ablaze several trucks carrying passengers on Sunday night, eyewitnesses and residents told Reuters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Sauerbrey
title: The Failure of Europe’s Feeble Muscle Flexing
description: A novel financial instrument was supposed to bring Europe strategic autonomy from the United States. Its muted debut only shows how far-off that goal really is.
content: BERLIN — If you don’t happen to be a foreign policy wonk, you’ve probably never heard of Instex, the Instrument in Support of Trade Exchanges. The company, set up by Germany, France and Britain in January 2019, was supposed to enable trade between Europe and Iran in defiance of United States sanctions. Now, a year later, the first transaction is just about to be processed, according to the German Foreign Office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: A Job Overseas, but Stranded by Coronavirus Travel Bans
description: A software engineer finds herself unable to return to her job in Hong Kong after the Philippine government banned travel to the city.
content: HONG KONG — Jade Doringo arrived at Manila’s international airport more than five hours ahead of her scheduled departure to Hong Kong, where she worked as a software engineer. But instead of getting on her flight, she was asked to surrender her boarding pass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley, Margot Sanger-Katz, Alan Rappeport and Emily Cochrane
title: Trump’s $4.8 Trillion Budget Would Cut Safety Net Programs and Boost Defense
description: The budget, while largely a messaging document, reflects the administration’s spending priorities’ stark contrast with the president’s Democratic rivals.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump released a $4.8 trillion budget proposal on Monday that includes a familiar list of deep cuts to student loan assistance, affordable housing efforts, food stamps and Medicaid, reflecting Mr. Trump’s election-year effort to continue shrinking the federal safety net.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penn Bullock
title: Cruise Ship, Oscars, North Korea: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Cruise Ship, the Oscars, North Korea
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember and Nick Corasaniti
title: Sanders and Buttigieg Close Out New Hampshire Pitching Different Visions
description: For months, the two candidates had rarely faced off in direct attacks. But now, as the polling leaders, they are using the other as a foil to press their divergent cases for the presidency.
content: SALEM, N.H. — Bernie Sanders stands before his audience reciting his familiar pitch, railing against the elite and declaring that America is “the only major country not to guarantee health care for all.” He directs his message to working-class voters and young people, vowing to make it easier to join unions and to legalize marijuana across the country. He is holding concerts to show off his big crowds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: New Campus Sexual Misconduct Rules Will Tackle Dating Violence
description: Education Secretary Betsy DeVos’s contentious regulations on sexual misconduct at schools will cement domestic and dating violence and stalking as forms of gender discrimination.
content: WASHINGTON — Education Secretary Betsy DeVos’s pending rules on sexual misconduct at the nation’s schools and colleges will include provisions to shore up protections for victims of stalking and dating violence, a response to lethal attacks that have underscored the weakness of current policies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: In ‘Amnesty,’ an Immigrant’s View Conveyed With Authority and Wit
description: Aravind Adiga’s new novel is about a Sri Lankan man trying to find his place in Australia who might have useful information about a murder.
content: Danny Rajaratnam, the protagonist of the bracing new novel by Aravind Adiga, “Amnesty,” has a vegan girlfriend. She looks at him and says things like: “You know what milk is? A kind of pus. Think about that, you’re guzzling pus.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Lil Wayne Scores His Fifth No. 1 Album With ‘Funeral’
description: Bundles and 135 million streams returned the rapper to the top of the Billboard 200.
content: Back in 2008, another era of the music industry — when the bad news was about piracy and record stores dying, and there wasn’t much good news — Lil Wayne stood out as a rare bankable star. His album that year, “Tha Carter III,” was a unicorn, selling more than a million copies in its first week out, and it instantly became a rap classic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock, Muktita Suhartono and Ryn Jirenuwat
title: Thai Soldier in Mass Shooting Had Business Clash With His Commander
description: The gunman operated in a military whose officers often have outside businesses and take advantage of lower-ranking soldiers. He killed 29 people, the worst shooting in recent Thai history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron E. Carroll
title: Lessons That Go Beyond the Coronavirus Outbreak
description: There are more useful things to do than worry. For one thing, you could wash your hands. (And did you get your flu shot?)
content: News of coronavirus infections is causing many people to panic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom
title: Weinstein Accuser Called Him Her ‘Spiritual Soul Mate,’ Witness Says
description: A friend of Jessica Mann’s testified for the defense that Ms. Mann had a relationship with the producer and never said that he raped her.
content: A former friend of Jessica Mann, a key accuser in the Harvey Weinstein rape trial, said on the stand that Ms. Mann had described Mr. Weinstein as her “spiritual soul mate” and that she had never said he had raped her.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump’s Reprisals: Firing Witnesses, Punishing New York
description: One reader says the firings confirm the need for whistle-blowers to remain anonymous. Another explains why the president can target New Yorkers with impunity.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Meet the Latinos Trying to Get Latinos to the Polls
description: A projected 32 million Latinos will be able to head to the polls in November. The Democratic presidential campaigns are hoping to engage them.
content: ﻿﻿A record 32 million Latinos are projected to be eligible to vote this November, putting them on track to become the largest minority voting bloc. They are far from single-issue voters, with education, health care, jobs, the economy and immigration all ranking as top concerns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Oscar for ‘Parasite’ Quenches Koreans’ Long Thirst for Recognition
description: As Bong Joon Ho’s film received Academy Awards for best picture and best director, the honors set off cheers and a burst of pride in a country fearful of being overlooked.
content: SEOUL, South Korea — Much of the world knows South Korea by its cultural products, including its increasingly popular movies, TV dramas and K-pop performers like BTS and Psy. Now the country has received once-unthinkable validation of its artistic achievement: a best-picture Oscar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: In ‘Amnesty,’ an Immigrant’s View Conveyed With Authority and Wit
description: Aravind Adiga’s new novel is about a Sri Lankan man trying to find his place in Australia who might have useful information about a murder.
content: Danny Rajaratnam, the protagonist of the bracing new novel by Aravind Adiga, “Amnesty,” has a vegan girlfriend. She looks at him and says things like: “You know what milk is? A kind of pus. Think about that, you’re guzzling pus.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: U.S. Charges Chinese Military Officers in 2017 Equifax Hacking
description: The indictment suggests that the breach was part of a series of thefts by China to use the data to target American officials.
content: WASHINGTON — Four members of China’s military were charged on Monday with hacking into Equifax, one of the nation’s largest credit reporting agencies, and stealing trade secrets and the personal data of about 145 million Americans in 2017.
source.name: The New York Times
